content: The Citation Success Index is a metric used to compare the citation capacity of pairs of journals [[2, (2016, Stasa Milojevic; J. Bar-Ilan)]]. It is defined as the probability that a random paper in one journal has more citations than a random paper in another journal. Unlike the Journal Impact Factor (IF), which is based on the total number of citations received by a journal's articles in a given period, the Citation Success Index takes into account the broadness and shape of citation distributions [[3, (2017, T. Milojevic; Judit Bar-Ilanb)]]. The metric grows slowly as a
